study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize ultrasonication conditions to improve oil recovery yield from palm oil mill effluent (POME) and assess the feasibility of converting the recovered oil into biodiesel.
results_summary: The study found that optimized ultrasonication (30.074% amplitude, 0.167 min duration, 2 cm probe depth) improved oil recovery yield by 42.50% compared to non-ultrasonicated POME. The biodiesel produced from POME-recovered oil met quality standards comparable to conventional palm-based biodiesel.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on POME, not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (ultrasonication parameters: 30.074% amplitude, 0.167 min duration, 2 cm probe depth).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of steam reforming (SR) using LaNiO3 and LaCoO3 catalysts for treating palm oil mill effluent (POME) and producing H2-rich syngas.
results_summary: The study found that LaCoO3 demonstrated superior coke resistance and longer operational stability (17 hours) compared to LaNiO3 (13 hours), with greater net H2 production (72.78%) and POME treatment volume (30.77%). SR achieved significant POME degradation (>97% COD, BOD5, TSS, and colour intensity), though further polishing was recommended for compliance.
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (POME) as the subject of treatment.
effective_dosage: 0.09 mL POME/min, 0.3 g catalyst, 74-105 μm catalyst particle size.
study_duration: 13 hours for LaNiO3, 17 hours for LaCoO3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of palm oil kernel shells, in combination with seashells, as coarse aggregate replacements in pervious concrete for removing heavy metals from stormwater runoff.
results_summary: The study found that incorporating palm oil kernel shells and seashells into pervious concrete at varying replacement levels (0%, 25%, and 50%) effectively removed heavy metals (Ba, Se, Cr, Fe, Cd, As, and Co) from stormwater, with analyses conducted using ICP-MS.
population_specificity: Stormwater runoff from commercial areas in Taman University, Skudai, Johor, Malaysia.
effective_dosage: Three replacement levels (0%, 25%, 50%) of palm oil kernel shells and seashells as coarse aggregates.
study_duration: 28-day curing period for pervious concrete samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a manganese-modified black titanium dioxide photocatalyst in treating palm oil mill effluent by reducing organic pollution indicators.
results_summary: The study found that the photocatalytic system achieved high removal efficiencies for chemical oxygen demand (88.87%), phenolic compounds (86.04%), color (62.8%), and total organic carbon (84.66%) under optimized conditions. Statistical analysis indicated high reliability of the results.
population_specificity: Treated agro-industrial effluent (TPOME) from the palm oil industry.
effective_dosage: 0.85 g/L photocatalyst loading, 0.048 mol/L H2O2 dose, 0.301 wt.% Mn concentration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of heat treatment using palm oil on the dimensional stability, hygroscopicity, and color of Afrormosia and Newtonia wood.
results_summary: Heat treatment in palm oil significantly improved the dimensional stability and hygroscopicity of both wood types, with reductions in swelling coefficients and water absorption. The effects were temperature-dependent, with higher temperatures yielding better results.
population_specificity: Afrormosia and Newtonia wood samples.
effective_dosage: Heat treatment at 160 °C, 180 °C, and 200 °C for two hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether replacing part of a palm oil-based high-fat diet with walnuts could prevent unstable atheroma plaque features in a mouse model of accelerated atherosclerosis.
results_summary: The palm oil-based high-fat diet induced features predicting unstable atheroma plaque (higher lipid content, necrosis, calcification) and more advanced lesions, while walnut inclusion attenuated these effects. The palm oil diet also increased inflammatory markers and defective efferocytosis, which were not observed in the walnut group.
population_specificity: Apolipoprotein E-deficient male mice (10-week-old)
effective_dosage: 43% of energy as fat (palm oil-based high-fat diet)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the treatment of palm oil waste through composting and review its applications for sustainable waste management.
results_summary: The study found that composting is an optimal and sustainable method for treating palm oil waste, with the in-vessel method being the most effective, producing high-quality compost in a minimum of 14 days. The results also highlighted the need for affordable, efficient, and practical technologies for sustainable waste management.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on waste management, not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of rumen-protected palm oil (3% of the ration) on lipid health indices and milk fatty acid composition in Kivircik ewes.
results_summary: The addition of palm oil increased palmitic acid (C16:0) and tended to increase saturated (SFA) and monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) in milk, but did not improve atherogenicity, thrombogenicity, or health-promoting indices. The omega-6/omega-3 ratio remained within a favorable range (0.61–2.63).
population_specificity: Two-year-old Kivircik ewes with similar parity, lactation stage, and body weight (52.57 ± 5.80 kg).
effective_dosage: 3% of the ration (coated with calcium salts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of palm oil tocotrienol-rich fraction (TRF) in preventing memory loss and neuropathological changes in type 2 diabetes-induced vascular dementia (VaD) rats.
results_summary: TRF treatment significantly improved memory, reduced biochemical markers of oxidative stress and neurodegeneration, attenuated histopathological changes, and increased PDGF-C expression in the hippocampus of VaD rats.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetes-induced vascular dementia (VaD) rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of producing poly(3-hydroxybutyrate) [P(3HB)] from untreated raw palm oil mill effluent (urPOME) using a mutant strain of Azotobacter vinelandii.
results_summary: The study found that the mutant strain effectively produced P(3HB) from urPOME, with optimization enhancing production nearly tenfold. The resulting P(3HB) exhibited superior crystallinity and tensile strength compared to sucrose-based P(3HB) and could be modified via electron beam irradiation for specific polymer applications.
population_specificity: Microbial (Azotobacter vinelandii ΔAvin_16040)
effective_dosage: 20% urPOME, 20 g L-1 sucrose, or 2 mL L-1 glycerol in basal medium

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of electrochemical oxidation (EO) as a pre-treatment for improving the disintegration and dewaterability of palm oil mill effluent (POME) waste activated sludge (WAS).
results_summary: The study found that EO using a ruthenium oxide-coated titanium electrode significantly improved POME WAS treatment, achieving >20% MLVSS removal, >43% CST reduction, <19% EPS increment, and >25% sCOD increment under optimized conditions (current density 17-27 mA/cm², electrolysis time 55-75 min, 10 g/L NaCl).
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (POME) waste activated sludge (WAS).
effective_dosage: Current density 17-27 mA/cm², electrolysis time 55-75 min, sodium chloride concentration 10 g/L.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel method for transforming crude palm oil into magnetic nanocarbon (MNC) using microwave-assisted arcing and evaluate its potential for wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The study successfully synthesized MNC with desirable properties (e.g., mesoporous structure, high fixed carbon content, and ferromagnetic behavior) and demonstrated its effectiveness in adsorbing Methylene Blue dye, achieving up to 87.79% removal efficiency. The adsorption system was found to be heterogeneous, with Freundlich isotherm models fitting better than Langmuir.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory-based material synthesis and testing).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (material synthesis conditions: 10-20 min synthesis time, 5-20 ppm Methylene Blue concentrations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if palm oil could prevent hypercholesterolemia-induced oxidative stress and inflammation in the liver of rats fed a high-cholesterol diet.
results_summary: Palm oil significantly reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines, lipid peroxidation, and improved antioxidant defenses and liver function indicators in HCD-fed rats. It also lowered the expression of fatty acid synthase (FAS) in the liver.
population_specificity: Rats fed a high-cholesterol diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the protective effect and mechanistic action of red palm oil (RPO) against LPS-induced hepatic injury in rats.
results_summary: RPO pre-treatment resolved LPS-induced hepatic dysfunction, reduced oxidative stress and pro-inflammatory cytokines, and improved antioxidant enzyme activity. It also modulated the Nrf2/GCL/HO-1 and NFκβ signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (10 animals/group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility of using palm oil as a sustainable dyeing medium for traditional grass cloth to reduce water and energy usage and minimize effluent production.
results_summary: The study found that palm oil/water dual-phase dyeing was effective for grass cloth, with optimized parameters (pH, temperature, time) improving dye distribution and color strength. Palm oil was recoverable up to 99% and reusable five times without compromising dyeing quality.
population_specificity: Traditional grass cloth (textile material)
effective_dosage: Not specified (dye powder dispersed in palm oil medium, 80-140% pick-up alkaline solution)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review microbial community dynamics in three biological treatment systems (composting, vermicomposting, and dark fermentation) to enhance the degradation processes of palm oil mill waste.
results_summary: The study identified dominant microbial communities involved in biodegradation processes of palm oil mill waste and highlighted the potential for improving degradation mechanisms to eliminate pretreatment needs and facilitate commercialization of waste treatment technology.
population_specificity: Microbial communities in palm oil mill waste.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of electrochemical oxidation using platinum as an anode for treating palm oil mill effluent (POME) by assessing chemical oxygen demand reduction, color removal, and total oil removal.
results_summary: Under optimal conditions (15V, 2h electrolysis time, 19.95 mg/L NaCl), the treatment achieved 84% COD reduction, 98% color removal, and 99% total oil removal, demonstrating platinum's effectiveness for POME treatment.
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (POME) samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to convert palm oil mill effluent (POME) and empty fruit bunch (EFB) into biomass fuel with high calorific energy value (CEV) while reducing waste accumulation.
results_summary: Co-fermentation of Lysinibacillus sp. and Aspergillus flavus yielded the highest CEV (26.71 MJ/kg), BOD removal efficiency (61.11%), COD removal efficiency (48.47%), and TSS reduction (37.12%). The study successfully transformed POME and EFB into renewable biomass fuel.
population_specificity: Laboratory-scale study using POME and EFB waste from palm oil production.
effective_dosage: Mixture ratio of POME to EFB was 7:3.
study_duration: 5 days of fermentation followed by overnight oven-drying.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the performance of anaerobic biofilm reactors in treating palm oil mill effluent (POME) and discuss recent advancements, limitations, and future perspectives.
results_summary: The study found that integrated anaerobic-aerobic bioreactors (IAAB) can remove over 99% of COD, BOD, and TSS from POME, outperforming UASB (80% COD removal) and UAF (88-94% COD removal). Anaerobic ponds also performed well (97.8% COD removal) but required longer retention times and more land.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on POME treatment technology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of using palm oil mill effluent (POME) as a carbon source for biohydrogen production through dark fermentation and assess the impact of chemical pre-treatments on efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that phosphoric acid (H3PO4) pre-treatment at 2.5% (w/v) maximized biohydrogen production (0.208 mmol/L/h) and carbohydrate utilization, with Thermoanaerobacterium thermosaccharolyticum being the dominant bacteria. Continuous fermentation further improved yield by 1.5-fold compared to batch fermentation.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study using POME as substrate)
study_duration: Not specified (batch and continuous fermentation conditions tested)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze consumers' preferences and willingness-to-pay for sustainability indicators on products containing palm oil, and assess the effect of factual information on these preferences.
results_summary: The study found that the 'organic' attribute received the highest monetary valuation among consumers, and providing additional information increased willingness-to-pay and reduced non-attendance for sustainability-indicating attributes. The 'organic' attribute was identified as the most promising for promoting sustainable palm oil use across consumer groups.
population_specificity: Consumers in Germany

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of calcium salts of palm oil (CPO) inclusion and feed amount on plasma GIP concentration, energy metabolism, and marbling score in feedlot steers.
results_summary: CPO inclusion and feed amount interacted to affect body weight, dry matter intake, and energy metabolism, with ad libitum-fed steers without CPO showing the highest intake and weight gain. GIP secretion was influenced by CPO and energy intake but showed no direct association with marbling score or respiratory quotient.
population_specificity: Sixty Angus × SimAngus-crossbred steers (initial body weight 279 ± 16 kg).
effective_dosage: Not specified (inclusion of CPO in feed, exact amount not detailed).
study_duration: 103 days (initial phase) followed by ad libitum access until harvest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anti-inflammatory and health benefits of tocotrienols (T3s) derived from palm oil, focusing on preclinical and clinical studies.
results_summary: The study found that T3s exhibit strong anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, with potential benefits for neurological, cardiovascular, and metabolic health, as well as skin protection and cancer prevention. Clinical evidence suggests T3s are safe and effective nutritional supplements with no evident side effects.
population_specificity: Preclinical models and human subjects, including patients with neurological or cardiovascular disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of chromium propionate and calcium salts of palm oil in ewes' diets during late gestation and lactation on progeny performance, carcass characteristics, and bone density.
results_summary: The study found that maternal diets with chromium propionate or calcium salts of palm oil increased progeny body weight, carcass yield, and prime cut proportions compared to the control group, without affecting dry matter intake or feeding efficiency.
population_specificity: Santa Inês and Dorper breed ewes (n=43) and their male lambs (n=23).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary inclusion levels not detailed).
study_duration: Final third of gestation and lactation (duration not specified), followed by 60-day confinement for lambs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current biological processing technologies for treating Palm Oil Mill Effluent (POME) to mitigate environmental and human health hazards.
results_summary: The study found that biological treatments, particularly using an upflow anaerobic sludge blanket reactor, were highly effective for POME treatment, achieving 99% COD removal with a hydraulic retention time of 7.2 days. Biological processing technologies were deemed efficient and sustainable for POME waste management.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on POME treatment technologies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to reduce harmful 3-MCPD ester and glycidyl ester (GE) contaminants in refined, bleached, and deodorized palm oil (RBDPO) using activated carbon adsorption.
results_summary: Activated carbon treated with 2 N HCl reduced 3-MCPD esters by 80% and GE by 97% in RBDPO at 35 °C, demonstrating effective contaminant removal.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on palm oil processing, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Activated carbon treated with 2 N HCl (AC 2 N) at adsorption capacity of 1.48 mg g-1 for 3-MCPD and 29.68 mg g-1 for GE.
study_duration: Not specified (batch system experiment, no duration mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of heat-treated palm oil fuel ash (POFA) on the strength, porosity, and water absorption of cement mortar.
results_summary: The study found that cement mortar containing 30% ultrafine treated POFA (u-TPOFA) heated at 600 ℃ (M2) showed the highest strength activity index (101.84% at 7 days, 107% at 28 days) and the lowest porosity (9.3%) and water absorption (4.5%). The improved performance was attributed to enhanced binding phases and filler effects from fine u-TPOFA microparticles.
population_specificity: Cement mortar mixtures (laboratory study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: 30% u-TPOFA blended with 70% ordinary Portland cement (OPC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize electrocoagulation parameters (current intensity, operation time, electrode gap, and initial pH) for treating palm oil mill effluent (POME) to enhance removal efficiency of pollutants.
results_summary: The study achieved optimal removal rates of 97.21% for COD, 99.26% for BOD, and 99.00% for SS using high current intensity (19.07 A), 44.97 min treatment time, 8.60 mm electrode distance, and pH 4.37, demonstrating high efficacy in pollutant removal.
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (POME) wastewater.
effective_dosage: 19.07 A current intensity (542 mA/cm² current density), 44.97 min treatment time.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the environmental impact of two integrated treatment processes (adsorption and electro-oxidation) for anaerobic-treated palm oil mill effluent (POME) using life cycle assessment.
results_summary: The electro-oxidation integrated membrane had a lesser environmental impact than the adsorption integrated membrane, particularly in ozone formation (human health). The study also found that environmental impacts varied by energy source, with Grid/Solar being the least impactful.
population_specificity: Environmental impact assessment (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of oil palm ash (OPA) and maturation pond effluent (MPE) for enhancing biogas upgrading (H2S and CO2 removal) and the effectiveness of hornwort cultivation for treating biogas scrubber effluent (BSE).
results_summary: The study found that OPA + MPE significantly improved CO2 and H2S removal efficiency in biogas, with optimal flow rates identified. Hornwort cultivation effectively treated BSE, reducing COD, nitrate, and phosphate levels while producing biomass.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on biogas treatment and wastewater, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: 0.7 kg/L OPA loading for scrubbing; 50-150 g wet weight hornwort for BSE treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of ultrasonication-treated palm oil mill effluent (POME) on anaerobic digestion efficiency and biogas production.
results_summary: The study found that sonicated POME increased biogas production (6.79 L vs. 4.5 L) and methane content (85% vs. 73%) compared to unsonicated POME, with Methanosaeta being the dominant archaea in treated reactors.
population_specificity: Anaerobic digestion reactors (laboratory-scale)
effective_dosage: Sonication power: 0.88 W/mL, sonication duration: 16.2 min, total solids: 6% w/v
study_duration: Hydraulic retention times of 15 and 20 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of palm oil mill effluent (POME) as an alternative nutrient source for Sporosarcina pasteurii cultivation and calcium carbonate bioprecipitation in soil.
results_summary: The study found that POME (40%, v/v) effectively supported bacterial growth and CaCO3 bioprecipitation, yielding 15.49 ± 0.05 g ml-1 after 21 days. Microscopic analysis revealed distinct crystal formations in soil treated with POME, indicating its potential as a cost-effective nutrient medium for biocementation.
population_specificity: Laboratory conditions (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance and limitations of existing POME pretreatment methods and explore the potential of advanced pretreatments using magnetic materials and natural composites as adsorbents.
results_summary: The study found that existing pretreatment methods (physical, chemical, coagulation-flocculation, and adsorption) can remove pollutants from POME but have limitations, while magnetic composite adsorbents show promise for enhancing treatment efficiency.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on POME treatment methods, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a bone-derived biocomposite for reducing chemical oxygen demand (COD) in palm oil mill effluent (POME) using a fixed bed column adsorption process.
results_summary: The study found that the bone-biocomposite was effective at reducing COD from POME, with optimal performance at a flow rate of 1.4 mL/min and breakthrough time of 5.15 hours. The adsorption process fitted well with the Adams-Bohart model, indicating high efficiency in COD reduction.
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (POME) in a laboratory setting.
effective_dosage: Influent flow rates of 1.4, 2.0, and 2.6 mL/min at pH 7.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal conditions for using potassium oxide supported on dolomite adsorbent to remove free fatty acids (FFAs) from crude palm oil (CPO).
results_summary: The adsorbent demonstrated 63% efficiency in FFAs removal, with optimal conditions at 30 min, 700 rpm stirring rate, 5 wt% adsorbent dosage, and 15 wt% K2O concentration. The Taguchi method simplified parameter determination and minimized costs.
population_specificity: Crude palm oil (CPO) samples.
effective_dosage: Adsorbent dosage (1, 3, 5 wt%), K2O concentration (5, 10, 15 wt%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the metabolic effects of palm oil-enriched high-fat diet (HFD) on nicotinamide-induced type 2 diabetic rats and assess the impact of metformin treatment.
results_summary: Continuous consumption of palm oil-enriched HFD altered metabolic pathways and caused detrimental effects in diabetic rats, while metformin combined with a normal diet mitigated some physiological impacts of diabetes.
population_specificity: Nicotinamide-induced type 2 diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of replacing palm oil with soybean acid oil on lipid class content and fatty acid digestibility in chickens.
results_summary: Replacing palm oil with soybean acid oil improved fat absorption in chickens at 11 and 35 days, though feed AME values and saturated FA digestibility at 11 days were unaffected. By 35 days, soybean acid oil and partial palm oil replacements showed comparable fat utilization to soybean oil.
population_specificity: 480 one-day-old female broiler chickens (Ross 308)
effective_dosage: Diets supplemented with 6% palm oil, 6% soybean acid oil, or combinations (e.g., 4% palm oil + 2% soybean acid oil)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of using palm oil industrial waste (oil palm biomass and POME) for sustainable biohydrogen production through biological methods like dark and photo-fermentation.
results_summary: The study found that palm oil industrial waste can be effectively used for biohydrogen production, with rates up to 52 L-H2/L-medium/h for solid waste and 6 L-H2/L-medium/h for liquid waste, though pre-treatment and optimal process conditions are crucial for efficiency.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on industrial waste and biohydrogen production, not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the characteristics of foulants in a submerged anaerobic membrane bioreactor (AnMBR) treating palm oil mill effluent (POME) and identify key contributors to membrane fouling.
results_summary: The study found that protein EPS in the cake layer was the primary contributor to fouling, with transmembrane pressure evolution indicating protein EPS attachment, adsorption, and entrapment in membrane pores. Hydrophilic charge of proteins and polysaccharides, along with feed composition and microbial metabolic products, significantly influenced fouling in high-rate operations.
population_specificity: Submerged anaerobic membrane bioreactor (AnMBR) treating palm oil mill effluent (POME).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on system performance, not human consumption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the electrocoagulation process for treating palm oil mill effluent (POME) to improve chemical oxygen demand (COD), color, and oil and grease removal efficiencies.
results_summary: The study found that electrocoagulation under optimized conditions (14V, 3h, 13.41 g/L electrolyte) effectively reduced COD (56%), color (65%), and oil and grease (99%) in POME. The best models for removal efficiencies were quadratic, with high R² values indicating strong predictive accuracy.
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (POME) samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exogenous ethylene gas application on post-harvested oil palm fruit bunches improves crude palm oil (CPO) quality and reduces contaminants.
results_summary: Ethylene gas treatment improved CPO quality parameters (free fatty acid, bleachability index, triacylglycerol) and reduced contaminants (phosphorus, chloride, iron, copper). It also corresponded with lower levels of harmful esters in refined oil.
population_specificity: Post-harvested oil palm fruit bunches.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of fertilizer-drawn forward osmosis (FDFO) using commercial fertilizers to treat anaerobic palm oil mill effluent (An-POME) for water and nutrient recovery.
results_summary: Mono-ammonium phosphate (MAP) showed the best performance in treating An-POME, with high water flux, low flux decline, and effective water recovery (5.9% in 4 hours, 15% in 24 hours). Hydraulic flushing and osmotic backwashing successfully restored water flux.
population_specificity: Anaerobic palm oil mill effluent (An-POME)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the physicochemical properties, extraction processes, nutritional benefits, and food applications of red palm oil.
results_summary: The study found that red palm oil retains β-carotene and vitamin E through specific extraction processes, contains a mix of saturated and unsaturated fatty acids, and may help overcome vitamin A deficiency, promote heart health, and exhibit anti-cancer properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review, not a clinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an integrated anaerobic/oxic/oxic scheme for treating high-strength palm oil mill effluent to reduce pollution and generate energy.
results_summary: The integrated treatment scheme achieved a 99.7% removal of chemical oxygen demand (COD), with anaerobic reactors removing 97.5% and aerobic reactors polishing the effluent. The system also generated yearly energy of 53.2 TJ, reduced emissions by 239,237 tCO2, and produced USD 1.40 million in revenue.
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (environmental application, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Trametes polyzona for bioremediation of phenolic compounds in Palm Oil Mill Effluent (POME).
results_summary: The study found that T. polyzona MPS1-3 significantly reduced COD, total suspended solids, total solids, and total phenolics in POME, demonstrating its effectiveness as a biotreatment agent. Maximum laccase production was achieved under optimized conditions, with the enzyme showing stability against metals, SDS, and EDTA.
population_specificity: POME samples collected in Côte d'Ivoire.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on enzyme production and biotreatment conditions).
study_duration: 10 days of incubation for laccase production.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential applications of palm oil clinker (POC) in environmental and engineering contexts, focusing on cost savings and performance.
results_summary: The review highlights POC's effectiveness in structural elements, wastewater treatment, highway construction, steel manufacturing, energy generation, and soil stabilization, emphasizing its sustainable and cost-efficient use compared to conventional materials.
population_specificity: Not applicable (review of existing research, not a clinical or experimental study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of photocatalytic technology for treating POME (palm oil mill effluent) waste, addressing the limitations of conventional treatment systems.
results_summary: The study found that conventional POME treatment systems are ineffective and produce excessive sludge, while photocatalytic technology shows potential for safer and more efficient POME waste treatment, though large-scale application remains challenging.
population_specificity: POME waste from palm oil mills in Indonesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of waste cooking palm oil-based carbon nanotubes (CNTs) as an adsorbent for heavy metal ions in wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The study found that WCPO-based CNTs exhibited high purity (89%) and crystallinity, effectively removing heavy metal ions (Fe (II) > Zn (II) ≈ Cu (II)) with removal percentages ranging from 99.2 to 99.9%. Optimal adsorption occurred at 1.8 g/L dosage in neutral pH (pH 7) for Cu (II), with high removal (~80%) even in acidic conditions (pH 2).
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on wastewater treatment).
effective_dosage: 1.8 g/L adsorbent dosage for Cu (II) solution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the survivability of Alcaligenaceae and Chromatiaceae as bioindicators for pollution in river water contaminated by palm oil mill effluent (POME) under varying environmental conditions.
results_summary: The study found that Alcaligenaceae and Chromatiaceae remained detectable despite fluctuations in temperature, pH, and total suspended solids (TSS), showing a positive correlation with biological oxygen demand (BOD5), confirming their reliability as pollution bioindicators. Bacterial functionality shifted under environmental stress, with viability decreasing at higher temperatures and pH but increasing with high TSS.
population_specificity: River water contaminated by POME final discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of using palm oil mill effluent (POME) as a substrate for microalgal biomass production and assess its wastewater treatment efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that Chlamydomonas biconvexa Embrapa|LBA40 effectively grew in POME, achieving high biomass productivity and significant reductions in ammonium, nitrite, and phosphate levels. The microalgal strain also showed potential for genetic modification and molecular breeding.
population_specificity: POME from anaerobic ponds of a palm oil industrial plant in the Amazon rainforest region.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of integrated copperas and calcium hydroxide in treating palm oil mill effluent (POME) to reduce environmental pollution.
results_summary: The study found that the integrated treatment removed 77.6% turbidity, 73.4% color, and 57.0% COD from POME, producing heavier flocs for improved settling. The Langmuir model best described the adsorption process, indicating monolayer adsorption.
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (POME) samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the quality and toxicity levels of palm oil mill effluent (POME) final discharge from different mills using chemical analyses and fish embryo toxicity tests.
results_summary: Mill A, which had a bio-polishing plant, showed lower pollutant levels (BOD, COD, TSS) and met discharge standards, while mills B and C exhibited higher toxicity, causing embryo malformation and mortality. The study found that bio-polishing effectively reduced pollutants, and the FET test was useful for monitoring POME toxicity.
population_specificity: Danio rerio (zebrafish) embryos
study_duration: Up to 96 hours for toxicity tests

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of integrated systems for treating palm oil mill effluent (POME) compared to conventional methods.
results_summary: Integrated systems combining conventional methods (e.g., biological with membrane, adsorption with magnetic field exposure) achieved over 90% removal of color, COD, and TSS, with reduced space utilization, improved treatment time, and simplified operation.
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (POME) in Malaysia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize struvite crystals in palm oil mill effluent (POME) and explore their potential for nutrient recovery.
results_summary: The study found high phosphorus and magnesium content in struvite crystals from POME, confirmed their composition via multiple analytical methods, and demonstrated a 67% reduction in phosphorus content through crystal growth experiments.
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (POME) treatment facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the removal of residual oil from palm oil-water mixtures (POME model) using the progressive freezing process.
results_summary: The study found that the optimal conditions for oil extraction were a coolant temperature of 6°C, freezing time of 50 minutes, and circulation flowrate of 500 rpm, achieving a 93.20% oil yield. The model's predicted and experimental yields closely matched, indicating high accuracy.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on POME model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palm oil vitamin E (tocotrienol-rich fraction, TRF) could prevent preeclampsia and pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) in pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found that TRF supplementation significantly reduced the incidence of PIH (adjusted OR 0.254) and preeclampsia (adjusted OR 0.030) compared to placebo. The results were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Primigravidae (first-time pregnant women) at a single urban tertiary hospital.
effective_dosage: 100 mg TRF daily in super-olein capsules.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the practicality and effectiveness of TiO2-photocatalysis for treating palm oil mill effluent (POME) in Malaysia, comparing it with biological-based treatments.
results_summary: TiO2-photocatalysis shows technical feasibility for POME treatment but is economically limited compared to biological-based treatments, which offer better performance and lower costs. Integrating TiO2-photocatalysis as a tertiary treatment for biologically-treated POME is more practical and enhances degradation efficiency.
population_specificity: Palm oil industry in Malaysia (POME treatment systems)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and compare non-conventional treatments for palm oil mill effluent (POME) to address its environmental impact.
results_summary: The study categorized POME treatments into five major routes, detailing their constraints, pros, and cons, and recommended specific treatments for primary, pretreatment, and polishing applications. Life cycle assessments were suggested for further evaluation of environmental, economic, and energy aspects.
population_specificity: Not applicable (review of treatment methods, not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of palm oil fuel ash (POFA) in enhancing biological wastewater treatment using sequencing batch reactors (SBRs).
results_summary: The study found that POFA significantly improved wastewater treatment efficiency, achieving optimal removal rates of 97.8% for COD, 99.4% for NH3-N, and 98.8% for color at a POFA concentration of 4 g/L and an aeration rate of 1 L/min. Higher aeration rates reduced floc size and decreased pollutant removal efficiency.
population_specificity: Domestic wastewater (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the prediction of palm oil mill effluent (POME) degradation efficiency using machine learning models to overcome the limitations of a previous quadratic model.
results_summary: The Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) model demonstrated high accuracy and generalization, achieving optimized POME degradation (52.52%) with minimal error (~3%). Other models (SVM, RTE) showed promising R2 values but higher RMSEs, indicating lower generalization.
population_specificity: Lab-scale photocatalytic system (not human or animal study).
effective_dosage: 70 mL/min of O2, 70.0 g/L of TiO2, and 250 ppm of POME concentration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of polypropylene micro/nanofiber (PP-MNF) in recovering residual oil from palm oil mill effluent (POME) and assess the quality of the recovered oil.
results_summary: The study found that PP-MNF effectively adsorbed residual oil from POME, with an average adsorption capacity of 10.93 g of oil/g of PP-MNF. The recovered oil quality was comparable to crude palm oil, with no polypropylene contamination detected, and PP-MNF showed reusability without significant physical changes.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of hydromethanolic seed extract of Lepidium sativum (HMSELS) on deep-fried palm oil diet-induced nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in male mice.
results_summary: The study found that HMSELS at 400 mg/kg/day significantly improved liver function tests (reduced ALT, total bilirubin, AST, ALP; increased albumin) and restored liver histopathology in mice fed a deep-fried palm oil diet. The protective effect was attributed to the antioxidant content of HMSELS.
population_specificity: Male mice aged 8-10 weeks, weighing 32-42 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of tannin as a natural coagulant for treating palm oil refinery effluent (PORE) to reduce environmental pollution.
results_summary: The study found that tannin effectively removed BOD (97.62%), COD (88.89%), turbidity (93.01%), and SS (90.21%) from PORE at optimal conditions (pH 6, 200 mg/L tannin dose, 60 min coagulation and sedimentation). The process was spontaneous, exothermic, and chemically driven.
population_specificity: Palm oil refinery effluent (PORE)
study_duration: 15-90 min coagulation time, 15-90 min sedimentation time

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of palm oil-based polyurethane as a biomaterial for soft tissue engineering applications, focusing on its biodegradability, biocompatibility, and mechanical properties.
results_summary: The study found that palm oil-based polyurethane exhibited high porosity, good tensile strength, thermal stability, enzymatic degradability, superior water uptake, and biocompatibility with cell adhesion and proliferation, making it suitable for soft tissue engineering.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of palm oil and palm olein on lipid parameters (TC, TG, HDL-C, LDL-C) as biomarkers for cardiovascular disease risk using in-vivo animal models.
results_summary: The review found significant positive outcomes in lipid parameters, particularly TC and LDL-C, suggesting palm oil and palm olein may act as lipid-lowering agents. The evidence supported their potential benefits, though controversies regarding cardiovascular risks remain.
population_specificity: In-vivo animal models (rats, hamsters, mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of immobilized microalgae cells in treating palm oil mill effluent (POME) by measuring biomass concentration and chemical oxygen demand (COD) removal.
results_summary: The study found that immobilized microalgae cells achieved a biomass concentration of 1.268 g/L and a COD removal of 72% at a 1:10 ratio of microalgae beads to POME. Higher ratios did not improve COD removal due to self-shading effects inhibiting microalgae growth.
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (POME) samples.
effective_dosage: Microalgae beads to POME ratios of 1:2.5, 1:5, and 1:10.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a feed additive containing fumaric acid and palm oil (FAPO) affected cattle performance, carcass characteristics, or economic return when included in diets with varying corn silage levels.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of FAPO on cattle performance, carcass characteristics, or economic return. Increased corn silage inclusion had a quadratic effect on some performance metrics but did not interact with FAPO.
population_specificity: Crossbred steers (480 animals, initial body weight 296 kg ± 24.1 kg).
effective_dosage: Not specified (included as part of feed additive with fumaric acid).
study_duration: 168–238 days (depending on corn silage inclusion level).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Klebsiella Pneumonia ABZ11 in decolorizing palm oil mill effluent (POME) under varying conditions.
results_summary: The study found that Klebsiella Pneumonia ABZ11 achieved over 80.40% color removal from POME under optimal conditions, closely matching the model-predicted value of 81.538%. The decolorization process was well-described by the Monod model, indicating high efficiency.
population_specificity: Palm oil mill effluent (POME) samples.
effective_dosage: Inoculum sizes of 5-25% (v/v), initial color concentration of 650-2,600 ADMI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate bioflocculant-producing bacteria from palm oil mill effluent for their effectiveness in dye removal from contaminated effluents.
results_summary: Bacillus nitratireducens (B4) showed the highest flocculating activity (49.15%) for kaolin clay and achieved over 90% removal of Eriochrome Black T dye under optimized conditions (pH 2, Ca²⁺ cations, 250 mL/L B4 dosage). The bioflocculant was found to be environmentally friendly and effective for effluent treatment.
population_specificity: Bacterial strains isolated from palm oil mill effluent (POME).
effective_dosage: 250 mL/L of nutrient broth containing Bacillus nitratireducens (B4).
study_duration: Eight hours of cultivation time for flocculating activity assessment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if washing crude palm oil (CPO) with hot water could reduce chlorine content and subsequent formation of harmful contaminants (3-MCPDE and GE) during refining.
results_summary: Hot water washing removed over 85% of chlorine, significantly reducing 3-MCPDE formation during refining, while post-treatment further lowered GE content. The method maintained other oil quality parameters like DOBI, FFA, and DAG.
population_specificity: Industrial-scale palm oil processing (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: 5 to 10% hot water (90 to 95°C) for washing CPO.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of palm oil mill effluent (POME) on the early life stages of Nile tilapia, focusing on hatching rate, survival, malformations, and deformities.
results_summary: Increasing POME concentrations significantly reduced hatching and survival rates while increasing malformation and heart rates in Nile tilapia larvae, with observed deformities including lordosis, kyphosis, and curved tail.
population_specificity: Early life stages of Nile tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the oxidation stability of high oleic oils compared to palm oil (PO) and identify factors influencing their thermal stability.
results_summary: The study found that palm oil exhibited slower oxidation initially due to tocochromanols, with a sharp increase in total polar compounds (TPC) after 72 hours. High oleic rapeseed oil (HORO) showed faster oxidation, likely due to higher polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) content.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on oils)
study_duration: Up to 84 hours of thermal treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a self-nano-emulsifying drug delivery system (SNEDDS) containing palm oil could enhance the oral bioavailability of pentoxifylline (PTX).
results_summary: The study found that SNEDDS with palm oil significantly improved the bioavailability of PTX by 1.5-fold compared to the pure drug, with optimized formulations showing a mean globule size of 165 nm and minimal turbidity.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the ability of the white-rot fungus Trametes hirsuta AK04 to metabolize phenolics in palm oil mill effluent (POME) and assess its potential for industrial wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The fungus effectively metabolized all tested phenolics, achieving 78-98% removal within seven days, with higher biomass yield at moderate concentrations (100-500 mg L-1). Mixed substrates and the addition of glucose/yeast extract enhanced degradation rates, demonstrating the strain's suitability for complex wastewater treatment.
population_specificity: White-rot fungus (Trametes hirsuta AK04) in laboratory conditions.
effective_dosage: Phenolics concentrations ranged from 100-1,000 mg L-1 (single substrates) and 1,000-6,000 mg L-1 (mixed substrates).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of palm oil mill effluent final discharge (POME FD) on the growth performance, lignocellulosic composition, and heavy metal content in P. purpureum.
results_summary: POME FD increased the growth of P. purpureum by 61.72% compared to rain water (14.42%) and significantly raised cellulose content (38.77% vs. 34.16%). Heavy metals in the plant were below WHO limits, indicating no adverse effects.
population_specificity: P. purpureum (a plant species used for phytoremediation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of tocotrienol-rich fraction (TRF) from palm oil on diabetes-induced retinal neurodegeneration and angiogenesis in rats, comparing oral and topical administration routes.
results_summary: Oral TRF supplementation significantly improved retinal layer thickness, reduced retinal cell apoptosis, and lowered VEGF expression in diabetic rats, while topical TRF showed no significant effects.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and potential cholesterol-lowering effects of oil palm phenolics (OPP) in healthy human volunteers.
results_summary: The study found that OPP supplementation was safe, with no major adverse effects, and improved total cholesterol and LDL-C levels compared to the control treatment. All clinical biochemistry profiles remained within normal ranges throughout the trial.
population_specificity: 25 healthy human volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immune-enhancing effects of lower doses (200, 100, and 50 mg) of tocotrienol-rich fraction (TRF) from palm oil in healthy individuals using an influenza vaccine as an immunological challenge.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study is proposed and not yet completed. It outlines the methodology and intended outcomes, including antibody levels, blood leucocyte profile, cytokine production, and correlations with plasma vitamin E levels.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 400 mg, 200 mg, 100 mg, 50 mg of TRF or placebo daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of tocotrienol-rich fraction (TRF) from palm oil with α-tocopherol (α-TF) supplementation on oxidative stress markers and vitamin D levels in older adults.
results_summary: TRF reduced malondialdehyde (MDA) levels in both sexes by 3 months and DNA damage in females by 6 months, while α-TF reduced MDA and protein carbonyl in females. Both supplements increased plasma vitamin D levels, with TRF showing a more pronounced effect in males.
population_specificity: Healthy male and female older adults aged 50-55 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of palm oil vitamin E (palmvitee) supplementation on immune response in smokers compared to nonsmokers.
results_summary: Palmvitee supplementation increased plasma tocopherol and tocotrienol levels and showed a trend of increased lymphocyte proliferation in both smokers and nonsmokers, but had limited effects on immune cell counts except for B cells in nonsmokers. Smoking altered certain immune parameters, but palmvitee did not significantly modify most of these changes.
population_specificity: Smokers and nonsmokers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the tocotrienol-rich fraction (TRF) of palm oil could prevent pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) in healthy first-time pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found a non-statistically significant trend toward lower PIH incidence in the TRF group (2.6%) compared to placebo (7.4%), with a 64% relative risk reduction. The results suggest potential benefits but require further validation.
population_specificity: Healthy primigravidae (first-time pregnant women) in an urban teaching hospital setting.
study_duration: From early second trimester until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of palmatine in treating sepsis-associated encephalopathy (SAE) in mice and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Palmatine improved nerve function, reduced brain cell apoptosis, lowered inflammatory cytokine levels, modulated the Notch1/NF-κB pathway, enhanced tight junction proteins, improved gut permeability, promoted beneficial bacteria, and inhibited harmful bacteria in SAE-induced mice.
population_specificity: LPS-induced SAE mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of palmatine on amyloid beta protein-induced cell and mouse models of Alzheimer's disease and investigate its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Palmatine increased cell survival, reduced apoptosis and inflammatory markers, improved learning and memory in AD mice, and modulated the Nrf2/HO-1 pathway to ameliorate oxidative stress and neuroinflammation.
population_specificity: Rat pheochromocytoma cells (PC12) and Alzheimer's disease mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect of Palmatine (PAL) on chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU) in rats, focusing on its role in alleviating symptoms, reducing inflammation, and activating autophagy.
results_summary: PAL treatment effectively reduced CSU-like skin lesions, itching, mast cell degranulation, and inflammatory factors while activating autophagy-related proteins, suggesting improved inflammatory response and autophagic flux.
population_specificity: OVA-induced CSU rat model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine induces mitophagy and its potential therapeutic effects on mitochondrial dysfunction, particularly in Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Palmatine efficiently induced mitophagy without impairing mitochondrial function, improved cognitive function in an Alzheimer's disease mouse model, and restored mitochondrial function in PINK1-knockout cells.
population_specificity: Human cell lines, PINK1-knockout MEFs, and an Alzheimer's disease mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine could inhibit the growth of canine mammary gland tumors (CMTs) and if this effect was mediated through the PI3K/AKT pathway.
results_summary: Palmatine reduced cell proliferation, induced cell death, and suppressed migration and tube formation in CMT cells and canine aortic endothelial cells. In vivo, it inhibited tumor growth, disrupted tumor vasculature, and reduced metastasis in a CMT-U27 mouse xenograft model.
population_specificity: Canine mammary gland tumor (CMT) cell line (CMT-U27) and canine aortic endothelial cells, tested in vitro and in a mouse xenograft model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of palmatine in treating neuroinflammation via the PI3K/Akt/NFkB pathway using computational and animal models.
results_summary: Palmatine improved learning memory, reduced anxiety, alleviated brain damage, and lowered inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β) in LPS-induced neuroinflammatory mice, acting through the PI3K/Akt/NFkB pathway.
population_specificity: LPS-induced neuroinflammatory mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine could reduce the virulence of Aeromonas hydrophila by inhibiting aerolysin production, thereby serving as a potential anti-infective agent in aquaculture.
results_summary: Palmatine reduced hemolysis by decreasing aerolysin production and suppressed the transcription of the aerA gene. It also decreased the pathogenicity of A. hydrophila in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Aquatic pathogens (Aeromonas hydrophila) and their effects in freshwater aquaculture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the combination of Berberine and Palmatine (Ber/Pal) could modulate neuroinflammation and improve cognitive function in Alzheimer's disease (AD) models, as well as assess the role of microglia-derived exosomes in drug delivery.
results_summary: The study found that Ber/Pal reduced inflammatory cytokine levels, improved learning and memory in APP/PS1 mice, restored neurons, inhibited Aβ plaque formation, and reduced microglial activation. Exosomes enhanced drug targeting and BBB penetration.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 mice (a model for Alzheimer's disease)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the main anti-liver fibrosis ingredients in Corydalis saxicola Bunting (CS) and elucidate the underlying mechanism of palmatine (PAL).
results_summary: The study found that PAL was the most important active ingredient in CS, effectively reversing abnormal gut microbial-mediated metabolites, improving intestinal barrier function, reducing hepatic inflammation, and rebalancing gut microbiota. Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) confirmed PAL's therapeutic efficiency was closely linked to gut microbiota.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal models based on methods, but not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism of Palmatine (PAL) in treating osteoarthritis (OA) and osteoporosis (OP) by analyzing its effects on gut microbiota and serum metabolites in rats.
results_summary: Palmatine improved bone microarchitecture and cartilage damage in OA-OP rats, restored gut microbiota balance, and altered serum metabolite levels, suggesting a potential therapeutic role via gut-microbiota-metabolite interactions.
population_specificity: OA-OP model rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Palmatine on neuronal damage, memory deficits, and inflammatory response in mice with permanent focal cerebral ischemia.
results_summary: Palmatine (2 and 20 mg/kg) reduced infarct size, neurological deficits, and memory impairments in ischemic mice, while also decreasing neuroinflammation markers like TNF-, iNOS, COX-2, and NF-κB. The 2 mg/kg dose showed sustained anti-inflammatory effects 96 hours post-ischemia.
population_specificity: Mice with permanent focal cerebral ischemia induced by middle cerebral artery occlusion (pMCAO).
effective_dosage: 0.2, 2, and 20 mg/kg/day, orally, once daily for 3 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess Palmatine's therapeutic potential and its working mechanism at the protein level in an Alzheimer's disease mouse model.
results_summary: Palmatine (10 mg/kg) significantly improved memory and learning in 5xFAD mice, demonstrated blood-brain barrier penetration, and altered protein expression in the cerebellum and hippocampus, reversing some Alzheimer's-related changes.
population_specificity: 12-month-old 5xFAD mice (Alzheimer's disease model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare Palmatine's effects on insulin resistance via the PI3K/Akt/GLUT4 signaling pathway against metformin and glimepiride in vitro, in vivo, ex vivo, and in silico.
results_summary: Palmatine reversed the downregulation of IRS-1, PI3K, AKT2, and GLUT4 and upregulated PKC-α in insulin-resistant cells, tissues, and animals, demonstrating potential to rejuvenate impaired insulin signaling.
population_specificity: Insulin-resistant L6 skeletal muscle cells, soleus muscle tissue, and STZ-induced Sprague Dawley rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of palmatine on LPS-induced oxidative stress, apoptosis, and depression-like behavior in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Palmatine significantly reduced apoptosis and ROS levels, improved mitochondrial damage, and alleviated depressive-like behaviors in mice by modulating the BAX/Bcl-2 and Nrf2/HO-1 signaling pathways. It also decreased levels of inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6) and increased SOD activity.
population_specificity: LPS-induced HT-22 cells (in vitro) and mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacological effects and mechanisms of Palmatine (Pal) on potassium oxonate/hypoxanthine-induced hyperuricemia (HUA) in mice.
results_summary: Palmatine significantly reduced uric acid, creatinine, and blood urea nitrogen levels, improved kidney histopathology, lowered hepatic enzyme activities, and mitigated oxidative stress and inflammation. It also modulated urate transporter proteins and inhibited the TXNIP/NLRP3 inflammasome pathway.
population_specificity: Mice with induced hyperuricemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmatine (PLT) has a protective effect against alcohol-induced acute liver injury and to explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: PLT attenuated alcohol-induced hepatocyte injury by promoting autophagy, upregulating ATG5 and ATG7, reducing proapoptotic proteins (Bax, Caspase 3, Caspase 9), and increasing antiapoptotic protein Bcl-2. The protective effects were mediated via the AMPK/mTOR signaling pathway and reversed by an autophagy inhibitor.
population_specificity: Cellular model of alcohol-induced acute liver injury (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanism of palmatine in treating Alzheimer's disease (AD), focusing on its effects on inflammation, apoptosis, and the PI3K-AKT pathway.
results_summary: Palmatine showed neuroprotective effects by improving learning and memory in AD mice, reducing inflammation markers (IL-6, IL-1β), and enhancing PI3K-AKT pathway activity. Molecular docking indicated strong binding to key targets like mTOR.
population_specificity: AD-induced mice and Raw 264.7 cells (murine macrophage cell line).
effective_dosage: 0.025 mg/ml to 0.5 mg/ml in cells; dosage in mice not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-viral activity of palmatine against infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) in chicken embryo kidney (CEK) cells and explore its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Palmatine demonstrated strong anti-IBV activity by directly inactivating the virus, inhibiting viral adsorption, penetration, and replication, and modulating NF-κB/IRF7/JAK-STAT signaling pathways and apoptosis-related genes. It also upregulated pro-inflammatory cytokines and type I interferon production.
population_specificity: Chicken embryo kidney (CEK) cells infected with IBV.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of Palmatine (PAL) on LPS plus MSU crystal-stimulated gouty arthritis in vitro and in vivo, focusing on its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.
results_summary: PAL dose-dependently reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-18, TNF-α) and oxidative stress markers (MDA), while enhancing antioxidant markers (SOD, GSH). It also inhibited NF-κB/NLRP3 signaling and activated Nrf2/HO-1 pathways, mitigating joint swelling and neutrophil infiltration in vivo.
population_specificity: PMA-differentiated THP-1 macrophages (in vitro) and MSU-induced arthritis mice (in vivo).
effective_dosage: 20, 40, and 80 μM (in vitro); dosage for in vivo not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects and mechanisms of Palmatine (PAL) and its metabolite 8-Oxypalmatine (OPAL) on DSS-induced colitis in mice, focusing on anti-inflammatory and antioxidant pathways.
results_summary: Both PAL and OPAL effectively reduced colitis symptoms, oxidative stress, and inflammatory markers in mice, with OPAL showing superior efficacy comparable to mesalazine at a lower dosage. The compounds activated the Nrf2 pathway and suppressed NLRP3 inflammasome activation.
population_specificity: Balb/c mice with DSS-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and validate palmatine as a functional MSI2 antagonist for inhibiting colorectal cancer cell growth.
results_summary: Palmatine was identified as a direct MSI2 antagonist that binds to MSI2's C-terminal and inhibits MSI2-dependent colorectal cancer cell growth. The study also revealed 38 candidate MSI2-targeted genes through transcriptome and proteomic profiling.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer HCT116 cells and non-small cell lung cancer A549 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory activity of palmatine on the metastatic colonization of triple-negative breast cancer cells in the lungs.
results_summary: Palmatine dose-dependently improved hypoxemia, reduced lung injury, decreased metastasis-associated protein MTA1 expression, and increased tumor suppressor p53 expression, demonstrating therapeutic potential against lung metastasis.
population_specificity: Female balb/c mice with transplanted 4T1 triple-negative breast cancer cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmatine (PAL) could alleviate LPS-induced acute lung injury (ALI) by inhibiting macrophage activation through NF-κB and p38 MAPK pathways.
results_summary: PAL reduced inflammatory cell infiltration (especially neutrophils), decreased TNF-α, CXCL-1, CXCL-2, and nitric oxide levels in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, and inhibited TAK1/TAB1 phosphorylation and downstream signaling in macrophages, demonstrating anti-inflammatory effects in ALI.
population_specificity: Bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDMs) and alveolar macrophages (AMs) in a murine model of LPS-induced ALI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether palmatine (PLT) could protect against doxorubicin (DOX)-induced cardiotoxicity in mice.
results_summary: PLT administration reduced myocardial injury, improved cardiac dysfunction, and suppressed DOX-induced inflammation, oxidative damage, and cardiomyocyte apoptosis in mice. The protective effect of PLT was counteracted by Sirt1 knockdown.
population_specificity: Mice with acute cardiotoxicity induced by a single intraperitoneal injection of DOX (15 mg/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of palmatine against amyloid-β-induced toxicity and its underlying mechanisms in vivo using transgenic C. elegans models.
results_summary: Palmatine delayed paralysis, reduced reactive oxygen species, upregulated resistance-related genes (sod-3, shsp), and reduced Aβ deposits and lipid metabolism dysregulation in Aβ-transgenic C. elegans.
population_specificity: Transgenic Caenorhabditis elegans models (CL2006, CL4176) expressing human Aβ 1-42.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate Palmatine (PLT) from Berberis cretica roots and investigate its cytotoxic and anti-proliferative effects, alone and in combination with doxorubicin, on human ER+/HER2- breast cancer cell lines.
results_summary: PLT inhibited breast cancer cell viability and proliferation in a dose-dependent manner, with IC50 values ranging from 5.126 to 5.805 µg/mL, without affecting normal breast epithelial cells. PLT also induced apoptosis and synergistically enhanced the effects of doxorubicin.
population_specificity: Human ER+/HER2- breast cancer cell lines.
interactions: Synergistic and additive interactions with doxorubicin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmatine (PAL) has a protective effect against ischemic stroke and cerebral ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury.
results_summary: PAL treatment reduced infarct volume, neurological scores, and brain water content in a mouse model of cerebral I/R injury. It also attenuated oxidative stress, inflammation, and neuronal apoptosis, with neuroprotective effects linked to the AMPK/Nrf2 pathway.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to transient middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) to mimic ischemic stroke and cerebral I/R injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine could alleviate mechanical facial pain in a rat model of trigeminal neuralgia by modulating P2X7 receptor expression, p38 phosphorylation, and proinflammatory cytokine levels.
results_summary: Palmatine reduced mechanical pain thresholds, decreased P2X7 receptor expression in trigeminal ganglia, lowered serum IL-1β and TNF-α levels, and reduced p38 phosphorylation in TN rats. These effects were comparable to those achieved by P2X7 shRNA inhibition.
population_specificity: Rats with chronic constriction injury of the infraorbital nerve (CCI-ION) to model trigeminal neuralgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of Palmatine on H. pylori-induced chronic atrophic gastritis (CAG) in rats and elucidate its metabolic mechanisms.
results_summary: Palmatine significantly improved body function, reduced serum biochemical indicators, and protected gastric mucosal integrity in CAG rats. Metabolomics identified 10 key metabolites and pathways, including taurine and glycerophospholipid metabolism, linked to its gastrointestinal protective effects.
population_specificity: Rats with H. pylori-induced chronic atrophic gastritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Palmatine's ability to reduce the up-regulation of chaperone proteins GRP78 and CALR and its effects on antioxidant and protective proteins in a diabetic rat model.
results_summary: Palmatine treatment down-regulated chaperone proteins (CALR and GRP78) and up-regulated antioxidant and protective proteins (Prdx4, PDIA2/3, GST, and ALB), suggesting it may mitigate oxidative and endoplasmic reticulum stress in diabetic conditions.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic Sprague Dawley rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effect of palmatine (PAL) on impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) in a high-fat diet-induced rat model and a cellular model of IGT.
results_summary: PAL improved glucose intolerance and insulin resistance in rats, increased β-cell mass, reduced β-cell apoptosis, and regulated MAPK signaling by inhibiting ERK and JNK cascades. It also promoted insulin secretion in PA-induced INS-1 cells via JNK signaling.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats and INS-1 cells (a pancreatic β-cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of palmatine on uterine mucosal epithelial cells, specifically its effects on protein expression and leukocyte migration during inflammation.
results_summary: Palmatine regulated the expression of cell adhesion molecules (CaMs), downregulating proteins involved in leukocyte migration (JAM1, NECT1, CDH5) while upregulating others essential for cell adhesion, suggesting it may modulate transepithelial migration during inflammation.
population_specificity: Goat endometrial epithelial cells (EECs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-cancer effects of palmatine (PAL) against colorectal cancer, focusing on its mechanisms involving AURKA inhibition.
results_summary: PAL significantly inhibited colon cancer cell proliferation in vitro and in vivo by inducing G2/M phase arrest and apoptosis via targeting AURKA, promoting ROS production, and altering mitochondrial membrane potential and apoptotic protein levels.
population_specificity: Colon cancer cells (in vitro and in vivo models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine could reduce pain transmission in trigeminal neuralgia by inhibiting the BDNF/TrkB pathway and suppressing ERK1/2 phosphorylation.
results_summary: Palmatine treatment increased the mechanical pain sensitivity threshold in TN rats, reduced BDNF and TrkB expression, and decreased ERK1/2 phosphorylation, suggesting it may alleviate pain by modulating these pathways.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats with induced trigeminal neuralgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile and review pharmacological studies on palmatine to highlight its potential applications beyond berberine, focusing on toxicity, pharmacokinetics, and biological activities.
results_summary: The review found that palmatine has been traditionally used for jaundice, liver diseases, hypertension, inflammation, and dysentery, with emerging evidence suggesting benefits for central nervous system-related conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine could alleviate trigeminal neuralgia by modulating CGRP expression, inflammatory cytokines, and PKC phosphorylation in a rat model.
results_summary: Palmatine significantly increased mechanical response thresholds, reduced CGRP and receptor expression, lowered IL-1β and TNF-α serum levels, and decreased PKC phosphorylation in trigeminal ganglia compared to untreated rats.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with chronic constriction injury of the infraorbital nerve (CCI-ION).
study_duration: 15 days (intervention from postoperative day 7 to day 15)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine could restore ciprofloxacin's effectiveness against Escherichia coli strains resistant due to plasmid-mediated quinolone resistance (PMQR) genes qnrS and aac(6')-Ib-cr.
results_summary: Palmatine synergistically restored ciprofloxacin's activity against resistant E. coli in vitro and reduced bacterial burden in a mouse infection model. It inhibited QnrS and AAC(6')-Ib-cr proteins by binding to their functional sites, reducing their protective and acetylation effects.
population_specificity: Clinical ciprofloxacin-resistant Escherichia coli strains and a mouse thigh infection model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine, a berberine analog, inhibits the growth of rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) cell lines.
results_summary: Palmatine suppressed the growth of RD cells but not other RMS cell lines. It also strongly inhibited tumorsphere growth in three-dimensional culture for RD cells.
population_specificity: Human embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (ERMS) cell lines (ERMS1, KYM1, RD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of palmatine in inhibiting Zika virus (ZIKV) and Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infections.
results_summary: Palmatine was shown to bind to restricted viruses, inhibit ZIKV infection, resist ZIKV-induced cytopathic effects, and inhibit JEV infection in multiple cell lines. The study suggests palmatine disrupts ZIKV binding, entry, and stability, making it a promising candidate for antiviral treatment development.
population_specificity: In vitro cell lines (specific cell types not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether palmatine could mitigate gentamicin-induced hepatotoxicity and nephrotoxicity in rats by reducing oxidative stress and apoptosis.
results_summary: Palmatine treatment reduced markers of liver and kidney damage (AST, ALT, BUN, creatinine), decreased oxidative stress (lower malondialdehyde, higher glutathione), and reduced apoptosis in gentamicin-exposed rats. It also improved renal function (urine flow rate, creatinine clearance, fractional excretion of Na and K).
population_specificity: Rats exposed to gentamicin-induced toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a fast, sensitive, and selective dual-mode (colorimetric and SERS) detection method for palmatine using bimetallic nanoparticles.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that NaHSO4-optimized Au@Ag NPs enabled rapid, sensitive, and selective detection of palmatine with a visible color change (orange to green) and enhanced SERS signals, achieving detection limits of 0.13 μM (naked eye) and 0.10 μM (UV-vis). Other protoberberine alkaloids did not interfere with the detection.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antitumor effects of photodynamic therapy (PDT) with Palmatine hydrochloride (PaH) on human oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) both in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: PaH-PDT exhibited potent phototoxic effects, inducing cell apoptosis, increasing intracellular ROS production, and upregulating p53 expression, leading to significant tumor growth inhibition and prolonged survival in tumor-bearing mice without obvious side effects.
population_specificity: Human OSCC cell lines and tumor-bearing mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effects of Palmatine on DSS-induced colitis in mice and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Palmatine significantly reduced disease activity index scores, improved colonic injury, enhanced mucosal integrity, inhibited cell apoptosis, modulated gut microbiota (increasing Bacteroidetes and Firmicutes while reducing Proteobacteria), and suppressed tryptophan catabolism by inhibiting IDO-1.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with DSS-induced colitis
effective_dosage: 50 and 100 mg kg-1, orally administered daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how palmatine interacts with and stabilizes G-quadruplex DNA, inhibiting telomere elongation and oncogene expression, relevant for anti-cancer therapy.
results_summary: Palmatine binds to G-quadruplex DNA sequences, inducing fluorescence enhancement and thermal stabilization (13-17°C), with structural insights revealing dual recognition sites and end-stacking/groove binding mechanisms.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal potential of palmatine (PAL) alone and in combination with fluconazole (FLC) and itraconazole (ITR) against Candida species, including C. albicans and non-albicans Candida strains.
results_summary: PAL demonstrated strong synergism with FLC and ITR, significantly enhancing their antifungal efficacy by inhibiting efflux pumps and increasing intracellular drug accumulation, as evidenced by reduced rhodamine 6G efflux and downregulation of efflux-associated genes.
population_specificity: Candida standard and clinical strains, including C. albicans and several non-albicans Candida species.
interactions: Synergistic effects with fluconazole and itraconazole were noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify compounds capable of inhibiting tau protein aggregation, focusing on palmatine chloride's potential to inhibit and disassemble tau aggregates in Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Palmatine chloride significantly reduced tau aggregation and disassembled preformed fibrils at sub-molar concentrations, demonstrating dual functionality in inhibiting and reversing tau aggregation. Molecular dynamics simulations suggested its interaction with key residues involved in β-sheet formation.
population_specificity: In vitro study using tau protein fragments and full-length tau.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine could alleviate diabetic neuropathic pain (DNP) and depression (DP) in rats by modulating P2X7 receptor expression and related inflammatory pathways.
results_summary: Palmatine treatment reduced hyperalgesia, allodynia, and depressive behaviors in rats with DNP and DP. It also decreased P2X7 receptor expression, inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-1β), and ERK1/2 phosphorylation in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Rats with comorbidity of diabetic neuropathic pain and depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of palmatine in treating cardiac hypertrophy and to explore its underlying molecular mechanism.
results_summary: Palmatine significantly reduced ISO-induced cardiac hypertrophy in rats, suppressed ANP, BNP, and HDAC2 transcriptions, and restored KLF4 and INPP5F expression in a dose-dependent manner, suggesting modulation of the HDAC2-KLF4/INPP5F pathway.
population_specificity: Rats with ISO-induced cardiac hypertrophy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of palmatine on LPS-induced inflammation in goat endometrial epithelial cells and explore its molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: Palmatine inhibited the release of TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, NO, MMP-9, and MMP-2 while enhancing PGE2 and IL-10 secretion. It downregulated TLR4, CD14, TRIF, and NF-κB expression but did not affect MyD88 production.
population_specificity: Goat endometrial epithelial cells (gEECs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the gastroprotective activity and underlying mechanisms of palmatine against acetic acid-induced gastric ulcers in rats.
results_summary: Palmatine significantly reduced ulcer areas and increased ulcer inhibition rates (51.42% and 60.92% at 10 and 20 mg/kg/day, respectively). It increased PGE2 levels and decreased PAF levels but had no significant effect on 5-HT and NE levels.
population_specificity: Rats with acetic acid-induced gastric ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel electrochemical detection method for palmatine in human serum and urine samples using a poly-l-lysine (PLL) and functionalized multiwalled carbon nanotube (f-MWCNT) composite.
