results_summary: The f-MWCNT/PLL composite demonstrated a wide linear response range (0.5µM to 425µM) and a low detection limit (0.12µM) for palmatine, with excellent performance in real-time monitoring of serum and urine samples. The system showed higher electrocatalytic activity, long-term stability, and low cost.
population_specificity: Human serum and urine samples (no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop cationic lipid emulsions (CLEs) for ophthalmic delivery of Palmatine (PM) to enhance its ocular residence time and evaluate its anti-infective efficacy.
results_summary: PM-loaded CLEs showed improved ocular residence time, sustained release, enhanced cellular uptake in corneal epithelial cells, and superior anti-infective activity in a fungal keratitis model.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely preclinical, in vitro and/or animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Palmatine's anti-Helicobacter pylori activity, its inhibitory effect on associated urease, and the underlying mechanism.
results_summary: Palmatine inhibited H. pylori strains with MIC values of 75-200 μg/mL, depending on pH, and significantly inhibited urease activity in a dose-dependent manner. The inhibition was reversible and targeted sulfhydryl groups, supported by molecular docking studies.
population_specificity: In vitro H. pylori strains (ATCC 43504, NCTC 26695, SS1, ICDC 111001) and urease enzymes (H. pylori urease and jack bean urease).
effective_dosage: MIC values of 75-200 μg/mL; IC50 values of 0.53 mM (HPU) and 0.03 mM (JBU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the photodynamic effect of palmatine hydrochloride (PaH) on apoptosis in breast cancer MCF-7 cells.
results_summary: PaH showed minimal cytotoxicity in the dark but demonstrated significant photocytotoxicity, induced apoptosis, and increased intracellular ROS levels in MCF-7 cells when exposed to visible light.
population_specificity: Breast cancer MCF-7 cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (cellular uptake reached maximum at 40 minutes).
study_duration: 24 hours post-photodynamic treatment for cytotoxicity assessment; 18 hours for apoptosis analysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the bactericidal effects of palmatine, a major component of Tinospora sagittata, against Helicobacter pylori in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Palmatine showed strong bactericidal activity against H. pylori, with MIC values of 6.25 μg/mL for a pig-derived strain and 3.12 μg/mL for the standard strain SS1. In vivo, palmatine achieved a 50% eradication rate in infected mice, comparable to triple therapy (70%).
population_specificity: Pig-derived H. pylori strain (SCYA201401) and standard H. pylori strain (SS1) in vitro; H. pylori-infected mice in vivo.
effective_dosage: In vitro: 0.5, 1, and 2× MIC (3.12–12.5 μg/mL); in vivo dosage not specified.
study_duration: In vitro: up to 48 hours; in vivo duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine induces osteoclast apoptosis via the NOS system and its potential as a bone resorption inhibitor for osteoporosis.
results_summary: Palmatine significantly reduced osteoclast cell survival at 40 μM, increased NO2 levels and iNOS mRNA expression, and induced apoptosis via the NOS system. Inhibition of iNOS prevented palmatine-induced osteoclast apoptosis.
population_specificity: Mouse preosteoclastic cell line (RAW 264.7) and mouse osteoblastic cell line (MC3T3-E1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of palmatine on gut inflammation and tumorigenesis in a high-fat diet-enhanced model of colorectal cancer.
results_summary: Palmatine demonstrated significant antiproliferative and anti-inflammatory effects in vitro and reduced tumor numbers and inflammatory cytokines in vivo, improving survival in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: ApcMin/+ mice (genetically engineered model for colorectal cancer) and HT-29/SW-480 human colorectal cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Palmatine hydrochloride (PaH) as a potential photosensitizer for photodynamic therapy on colon adenocarcinoma HT-29 cells.
results_summary: PaH showed no cytotoxicity in the dark but demonstrated significant photocytotoxicity when activated by 470nm light, inducing apoptosis in HT-29 cells in a concentration- and light dose-dependent manner. Maximum cellular uptake occurred at 40 minutes, with PaH localizing in mitochondria.
population_specificity: Colon adenocarcinoma HT-29 cells and NIH-3T3 normal cells (in vitro).
study_duration: 24 hours for dark toxicity, 40 minutes for cellular uptake, and 18-24 hours post-photodynamic treatment for apoptosis assessment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of palmatine on osteoarthritis in a rabbit model, both in vivo and in vitro, focusing on its impact on chondrocytes and signaling pathways.
results_summary: Palmatine reduced MMP expression, increased TIMP-1 synthesis, and inhibited collagenase II and aggrecan degradation. It also modulated Wnt/β-catenin and Hedgehog signaling pathways, demonstrating protective effects on articular cartilage.
population_specificity: Rabbit osteoarthritis model and IL-1β-stimulated rabbit chondrocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine inhibits osteoclast differentiation and bone resorption by affecting RANKL and OPG expression in ovariectomized mice and osteoblast-like cells.
results_summary: Palmatine significantly reduced osteoclast numbers in tissues and decreased RANKL and OPG expression in both mice and cultured MC3T3-E1 cells, suggesting it may attenuate osteoclast differentiation.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized mice and osteoblast-like cells (MC3T3-E1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hypolipidemic effect and mechanism of palmatine in hamsters fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: Palmatine reduced serum cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL-C while increasing fecal excretion of cholesterol and bile acids. It also modulated gene and protein expression related to cholesterol metabolism, suggesting potential as a natural cholesterol-lowering agent.
population_specificity: Hyperlipidemic hamsters

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal effects of palmatine hydrochloride, both alone and in combination with berberine hydrochloride, against Microsporum canis in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Palmatine showed antifungal activity by damaging the cell membrane and organelles of M. canis and upregulating specific genes, with combined treatment being more effective than single administration or clotrimazole. Clinical results confirmed the enhanced efficacy of the combination therapy in treating M. canis infections in rabbits.
population_specificity: Rabbits infected with Microsporum canis.
effective_dosage: Minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) of palmatine was 1 mg/mL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine, a component of Nexrutine, selectively inhibits prostate cancer cell growth and tumor invasion by targeting the rpS6/NFκB/FLIP axis.
results_summary: Palmatine selectively inhibited prostate cancer cell growth without affecting non-tumorigenic prostate epithelial cells, reduced activation of NFκB and its downstream target FLIP, and inhibited tumor invasion. These effects were consistent with those of the parent extract Nexrutine, suggesting palmatine's potential as a cytotoxic and anti-invasive agent.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer cells (in vitro and in vivo models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pharmacokinetics of palmatine in normal rats versus metabolic syndrome rats after oral administration of San-Huang formula extract.
results_summary: The study found that palmatine had higher uptake and slower elimination in metabolic syndrome rats compared to normal rats, indicating altered drug metabolism in metabolic syndrome. The pharmacokinetic parameters (AUC0-t, Cmax, Vd, and CL) were significantly different between the two groups.
population_specificity: Normal and metabolic syndrome rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine inhibits osteoclast differentiation and bone resorption, potentially serving as an anti-resorptive agent for bone disorders like osteoporosis.
results_summary: Palmatine inhibited osteoclast differentiation by suppressing RANKL expression in osteoblasts and disrupted actin ring formation in mature osteoclasts, reducing bone resorption. It did not affect RANKL-induced osteoclast formation but showed significant inhibitory effects in co-culture systems.
population_specificity: Mouse bone marrow cells (BMC) and osteoblasts in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine has cytoprotective effects against GalN/LPS-induced fulminant hepatic failure in mice by modulating cytokine responses and inhibiting apoptosis.
results_summary: Palmatine attenuated GalN/LPS-induced liver injury by reducing serum TNF-alpha levels, increasing IL-10 levels, and decreasing hepatocyte apoptosis, though it did not affect lipid peroxidation or glutathione content.
population_specificity: Mice with GalN/LPS-induced fulminant hepatic failure.
effective_dosage: 25, 50, 100, and 200 mg/kg administered once before GalN/LPS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hypoglycemic activity of a palmatine derivative (11-hydroxypalmatine) in alloxan-induced diabetic mice.
results_summary: The study found that 11-hydroxypalmatine significantly reduced blood glucose levels by 52% in diabetic mice, comparable to the positive control glibenclamide (54%) and outperforming the diabetic control (27%). The compound was effective at doses of 25, 50, and 100 mg/kg.
population_specificity: Alloxan-induced diabetic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how DNA binding affects the photosensitized singlet oxygen (1O2) generation activity of palmatine and its potential application in photodynamic therapy.
results_summary: The study found that palmatine generates singlet oxygen (1O2) only when bound to DNA, with DNA binding significantly prolonging the photoexcited state lifetime. This interaction enhances intersystem crossing and energy transfer to molecular oxygen, suggesting potential for controlled photosensitizer design in medical applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method for identifying and elucidating the structures of palmatine metabolites in rat urine after a single dose.
results_summary: The study identified six phase I metabolites, the parent drug palmatine, and two phase II metabolites in rat urine using a high-performance liquid chromatography/electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometric method.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmatine could inhibit West Nile virus (WNV) NS2B-NS3 protease activity and viral propagation, as well as its potential effects on other flaviviruses.
results_summary: Palmatine inhibited WNV NS2B-NS3 protease uncompetitively (IC50 = 96 µM) and suppressed WNV replication (EC50 = 3.6 µM) without cytotoxicity (CC50 = 1,031 µM). It also showed dose-dependent suppression of dengue and yellow fever viruses.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: IC50 = 96 µM, EC50 = 3.6 µM, CC50 = 1,031 µM (concentrations, not dosages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism of DNA damage caused by photoexcited palmatine and its interaction with DNA, specifically focusing on guanine-specific photooxidation via singlet oxygen (1O2) formation.
results_summary: Photoexcited palmatine binds to DNA, forming stable fluorescent complexes, and induces guanine-specific DNA cleavage via 1O2 generation, confirmed by HPLC measurement of 8-oxodGuo formation. The effect was observed only under aerobic conditions and was inhibited by singlet oxygen scavengers.
population_specificity: Human DNA fragments (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent literature on Banxia Xiexin Decoction (BXD) and its bioactive components, including palmatine, to explore their pharmacological basis for treating gastrointestinal diseases (GIDs).
results_summary: Palmatine, identified as a bioactive component in the bitter group of BXD, was found to contribute to the decoction's effects on GIDs, either directly or indirectly, alongside other compounds like berberine and baicalein. The study suggests these components collectively enhance BXD's therapeutic outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of natural products, including Palmatine, in managing diabetes by targeting key enzymes and gut microbiota.
results_summary: Palmatine, isolated from Dichocarpum auriculatum, was identified as a powerful cholinesterase inhibitor, suggesting a potential role in managing diabetes and its complications. The study highlights its efficacy among other plant-derived compounds in modulating enzyme activity linked to diabetes.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing literature on the effects of palmatine supplementation on metabolic syndrome (MetS) and its complications, focusing on its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: The review found that palmatine may protect against MetS and related diseases like cardiovascular diseases, osteoporosis, and osteoarthritis, primarily through its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects. However, these findings are based on preclinical studies, with no human clinical trials conducted to validate efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (animal or in vitro models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the traditional uses, phytochemistry, and pharmacology of T. foliolosum, including its alkaloids like palmatine, to explore its therapeutic potential for human disorders.
results_summary: The study identified palmatine as one of several alkaloids in T. foliolosum, attributing therapeutic effects to these compounds, but did not specifically detail palmatine's individual efficacy. The herb was noted for its potential in drug development without reported toxicity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmacology, toxicity, and pharmacokinetics of palmatine to explore its therapeutic potential and identify ways to reduce toxicity.
results_summary: Palmatine exhibits broad pharmacological effects, including anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective properties, but has notable DNA toxicity and complex effects on liver metabolic enzymes. Its main metabolic pathways are glucuronidation and sulfation.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms of Rhizoma coptidis active ingredients, including palmatine, in treating Alzheimer's disease (AD) and vascular dementia (VaD).
results_summary: Palmatine was noted to regulate blood lipids and blood pressure, but there were relatively few studies on its effects compared to other ingredients like berberine. The abstract suggests potential benefits but lacks detailed findings specific to palmatine.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the metabolism of protoberberine alkaloids, including palmatine, across different species.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for palmatine but indicates that protoberberine alkaloids, including palmatine, have been used to treat various conditions such as cancer, inflammation, diabetes, and hypertension.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focuses on metabolism across species).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic potential and mechanisms of action of berberine (not Palmatine) in treating musculoskeletal disorders.
results_summary: Berberine may help slow osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, and rheumatoid arthritis progression and suppress osteosarcoma cell proliferation by targeting multiple signaling pathways, exhibiting anti-apoptotic, anti-inflammatory, and immunosuppressive properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: To provide an up-to-date, comprehensive overview and analysis of the ethnobotany, phytochemistry, and pharmacology of Stephania rotunda, including Palmatine, for its potential benefits in human health.
results_summary: The study identified Palmatine (l-THP) as one of the main alkaloids in Stephania rotunda, with noted pharmacological activities including antiplasmodial, anticancer, and immunomodulatory effects. Toxicity has been evaluated for l-THP, but specific safety and efficacy data for Palmatine were not detailed.
population_specificity: Traditional medicine users in Southeast Asia (Cambodia, Vietnam, Laos, India).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the interaction of Palmatine and other isoquinoline alkaloids with nucleic acids to understand their binding mechanisms and potential for drug design.
results_summary: The study found that Palmatine and related alkaloids exhibit significant nucleic acid-binding properties, with ongoing research elucidating their specificity, energetics, and potential therapeutic applications, particularly in anticancer drug discovery.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory and antinociceptive activities of Palmatine derived from Radix Tinosporae.
results_summary: Palmatine showed significant inhibitory effects on xylene-induced ear edema and acetic acid-induced writhing in mice, and it markedly inhibited nitric oxide production and NF-kappaB activation in macrophage cells.
population_specificity: Mice (in vivo) and RAW264.7 macrophage cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticholinesterase and antioxidant properties of Berberis species, including palmatine, for potential use in Alzheimer's disease treatment.
results_summary: Palmatine showed inhibitory activity against acetylcholinesterase (AChE) with an IC50 of 7.4 μg/ml, though it was less potent than berberine. The study highlighted the potential of Berberis extracts and isolated compounds, including palmatine, for Alzheimer's disease treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmatine, as a constituent of OGT, inhibits IDO-1 activity and contributes to cognitive improvement in Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Palmatine exhibited irreversible inhibition of recombinant human IDO-1 (rhIDO-1) in vitro, demonstrating potent IDO-1 inhibitory activity comparable to other OGT constituents. Its IC50 values were lower than the commonly used IDO-1 inhibitor 1-MT, suggesting strong therapeutic potential for AD.
population_specificity: In vitro study using recombinant human IDO-1 and HEK 293 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of hydrodispersible palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) combined with melatonin in reducing migraine frequency, intensity, duration, and disability.
results_summary: The study found that the PEA-melatonin combination significantly reduced migraine frequency, duration, intensity, and disability after three months of treatment, with no reported adverse effects. A notable mitigation of migraine-related symptoms was also observed.
population_specificity: 60 migraine patients (30 in treatment group, 30 in placebo group) recruited by the I.N.B.B. Consortium in Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether co-ultramicronized palmitoylethanolamide combined with luteoline could slow cognitive and functional decline in frontotemporal dementia patients.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significantly less decline in the primary outcome measure (CDR plus NACC FTLD-SoB) compared to placebo, with a mean difference of 0.86 (P = 0.005). Secondary measures like activities of daily living and aphasia screening also showed less decline in the treatment group, though no effect was observed on other secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: 48 patients with probable frontotemporal dementia (mean age 63.2, 47.9% female).
effective_dosage: 700 mg palmitoylethanolamide + 70 mg luteoline twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) is effective and safe for reducing menstrual pain compared to a placebo.
results_summary: PEA significantly reduced menstrual pain scores at multiple time points (1, 1.5, 2, and 2.5 hours post-dosage) compared to placebo, with no differences in treatment satisfaction, rescue medication use, or adverse events.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 in Australia experiencing menstrual pain.
effective_dosage: 300 mg at pain onset, with a second dose permitted after 2 hours if pain persisted.
study_duration: Single intervention per menstrual cycle, with pain monitored for up to 4 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review RCTs evaluating the efficacy and tolerability of PEA supplementation across various human illnesses.
results_summary: PEA demonstrated strong evidence for pain management and general wellbeing, with good tolerability and potential disease-modifying effects through biomarker modulation. The strongest results were observed with ultramicronized/micronized or cold-water dispersible formulations.
population_specificity: Patient populations with neuropsychiatric, neurological, somatic, and visceral disturbances, as well as those monitored for biomarker changes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in alleviating pain across various pathologies, including nociceptive, neuropathic, and nociplastic pain, through a comprehensive meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that PEA significantly reduced pain at 6, 8, and 24-26 weeks and improved quality of life, with benefits observed across all pain types. PEA was shown to be a promising alternative to chronic opioid analgesics, potentially reducing opioid abuse risk.
population_specificity: 1196 patients across 18 randomized clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in managing metabolic syndrome in postmenopausal women by examining its effects on lipid metabolism, inflammation, and neuropsychological health.
results_summary: PEA may promote browning of white adipocytes, improve lipid profiles, enhance insulin sensitivity, and aid in weight management. It also shows potential neuroprotective effects, but further clinical studies are needed to confirm efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women at risk of or with metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, safety, and potential efficacy of ultramicronized-PEA (um-PEA) in reducing attenuated psychotic symptoms and psychic distress in young adults at Clinical High-Risk for psychosis (CHR).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study is described as a planned proof-of-concept trial.
population_specificity: Young adults at Clinical High-Risk for psychosis (CHR) presenting with attenuated psychotic symptoms (APS).
study_duration: 12-week initial phase, with an optional 24-week extension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) could improve symptoms of established chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) in patients who had completed paclitaxel, oxaliplatin, or cisplatin-based chemotherapy.
results_summary: PEA did not show any improvement in CIPN symptoms compared to placebo, with no significant differences in quality of life or cognitive function outcomes. There were no notable toxicity differences between PEA and placebo arms.
population_specificity: Adults with CIPN symptoms (pain, numbness, tingling) for at least three months after completing paclitaxel, oxaliplatin, or cisplatin-based chemotherapy (17 males, 71 females; most had neuropathy from paclitaxel).
effective_dosage: PEA administered once or twice daily (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether inhibiting endogenous PEA degradation and administering exogenous PEA could reduce chronic and acute hyperalgesia in sickle cell disease (SCD) mice by targeting peripheral and central pain mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that PEA reduced chronic hyperalgesia by inhibiting spinal inflammation, oxidative stress, and p38-MAPK activity, while also preventing acute hyperalgesia in sickle mice. PEA also reduced mast cell activation and inflammation markers in the periphery.
population_specificity: Humanized transgenic HbSS-BERK mice (a model of sickle cell disease) compared to healthy HbAA control mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological properties, efficacy, and clinical applications of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in pain-related conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: PEA demonstrated effectiveness in reducing pain and inflammation by modulating PPAR α and endocannabinoid receptors, lowering oxidative stress, and decreasing pro-inflammatory cytokines. It also reduced the need for higher dosages of other drugs, minimizing toxicity risks.
population_specificity: Neuropathic pain and neurodegenerative disease models (e.g., multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the effects of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) on brain function and lipid chemistry using MRI and lipidomics in awake rats.
results_summary: PEA treatment showed an inverse dose-response for negative BOLD signal (suggesting decreased brain activity) but a dose-dependent increase in functional connectivity in key brain regions. It also significantly altered CNS levels of PEA and numerous endogenous lipids, including reduced Anandamide and other endolipids.
population_specificity: Awake rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent literature on Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) to evaluate its appropriateness in neuropathic and mixed pain management and explore innovative formulations.
results_summary: The study found PEA effective in managing neuropathic and mixed pain, with potential anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and analgesic properties. An innovative formulation (Equisetum-PEA) showed improved bioavailability and targeted distribution.
population_specificity: Individuals with neuropathic or mixed pain, chronic inflammation, and oxidative stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antinociceptive properties, motor coordination, and constipation effects of tramadol and PEA in combination within a neuropathic pain model.
results_summary: PEA was approximately five and eightfold more potent than tramadol in producing anti-hyperalgesic and anti-allodynic effects, respectively. The combination of TRA 10 mg/kg + PEA 0.0316 mg/kg showed the most pronounced antinociceptive effects without significant side effects.
population_specificity: 126 male Wistar rats with a CCI model of neuropathic pain.
effective_dosage: PEA (0.0316-10 mg/kg), TRA (1.0-31.62 mg/kg), or TRA (1.0-10 mg/kg) with PEA (0.0316-1.0 mg/kg), administered orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the biobehavioral effects of ultramicronized-PEA (um-PEA) as a monotherapy for psychic distress in autistic adults with varying severity levels.
results_summary: The level 1 autistic patient showed improved depressive symptoms and social engagement at 12 weeks, with reduced inflammatory response and enhanced endocannabinoid signaling, while the level 2 patient exhibited stable psychosocial functioning initially but deteriorated later, leading to antipsychotic initiation. No significant side effects were reported in either case.
population_specificity: Autistic adults (level 1 and level 2 severity) with symptoms of psychic distress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of palmitoylethanolamide (PEA), alone or combined with plant extracts, as a complementary strategy for managing GERD by reducing inflammation in esophageal cells.
results_summary: PEA significantly reduced the inflammatory response in esophageal cells exposed to HCl, and its effect was enhanced when combined with extracts of Zingiber officinale, Musa × paradisiaca, Opuntia ficus-indica, and Olea europaea. The study suggests PEA as a promising natural anti-GERD compound.
population_specificity: In vitro esophageal mucosa CP-B cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether VEGF-A is involved in PEA-induced delay of morphine tolerance and whether PEA modulates VEGF-A and sFLT-1 levels in the nervous system and plasma.
results_summary: Ultramicronized PEA delayed morphine tolerance, enhanced morphine's analgesic effect, and reduced morphine-induced increases in VEGF-A and sFLT-1. PEA also counteracted pain-related gene expression in the spinal cord and DRG.
population_specificity: In vivo models (animal study).
interactions: Interacts with morphine, enhancing its analgesic effect and delaying tolerance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a nutraceutical formulation combining melatonin and palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) for preventing and treating immune-mediated allergic reactions.
results_summary: The study found that the formulation reduced COX-2 mRNA transcription levels (-30%), enzymatic activity (IC50: 152 μg/mL), and decreased histamine, β-hexosaminidase, TNF-α, and IL-6 release in stimulated human mast cells.
population_specificity: Human mast cell line (HMC-1.2)
effective_dosage: Bioaccessible concentrations of PEA (1.6%) and melatonin (36%)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) could alleviate anxiety- and depression-like behaviors induced by morphine withdrawal and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: PEA reduced anxiety and depression symptoms in mice undergoing morphine withdrawal and lowered levels of monoamine neurotransmitters (5-hydroxytryptamine, noradrenaline, dopamine) in the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to morphine treatment and withdrawal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of elastic nano-liposomes (ENLs) as a novel delivery system for Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) to enhance its transdermal delivery and skincare functionalities.
results_summary: PEA-loaded ENLs demonstrated efficient transdermal delivery, enhanced skin retention, and significant regulation of genes related to anti-nociceptive, anti-inflammatory, and skin barrier repair effects, with no cytotoxicity or allergic reactions observed.
population_specificity: HaCaT cells and human skin patch test participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a daily combination of palmitoylethanolamide and melatonin on pain, sleep, and quality of life in fibromyalgia patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain (VAS), insomnia (ISI), and health assessments (HAQ), along with reduced tender points, maintained even after discontinuation. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: 50 fibromyalgia patients (2016 ACR criteria), average age 54.12 years, 3:1 female-to-male ratio.
effective_dosage: 1200 mg palmitoylethanolamide and 0.2 mg melatonin daily.
study_duration: 3 months of treatment, with a 1-month follow-up (total 4 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) and luteolin (LUT) with olfactory training (OT) improves olfactory function in patients with post-viral olfactory dysfunction, primarily after COVID-19.
results_summary: The study found that PEA-LUT combined with OT led to significant improvements in odor discrimination and overall olfactory function (TDI score) compared to OT alone, though clinically meaningful improvements did not significantly differ between groups. The results suggest PEA-LUT may have potential benefits but limited additional advantage over OT alone.
population_specificity: Patients with persistent olfactory dysfunction following upper respiratory tract infections, mainly COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether extended treatment with micron-size Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) provides greater pain relief in chronic pain management compared to shorter durations.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a statistically and clinically significant reduction in pain intensity after 60 days of micron-size PEA supplementation compared to 30 days, with a 35.1% pain reduction in the first month and an additional 35.4% in the second month. The results support the time-dependent efficacy of PEA for chronic pain relief.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic pain (742 participants across nine studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Palmitoylethanolamide combined with Epilobium and Calendula extract in reducing symptoms of chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome type III (CP/CPPS III).
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in NIH-CPSI scores, urinary leukocytes, PSA levels, erectile function (IIEF-5), peak flow, post-void residual volume, and pain (VAS score) after one month of treatment. The benefits were attributed to reduced inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: 45 patients aged 18-75 with CP/CPPS III (NIH category III) and symptoms lasting ≥3 months.
effective_dosage: 1 rectal suppository daily (containing PEA, Epilobium, and Calendula).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) supplementation combined with resistance training affects lean body mass, strength, power, sleep, and wellbeing compared to placebo.
results_summary: PEA supplementation did not impair lean mass gains and resulted in significantly higher dynamic lower-body power (jump height) compared to placebo, though the placebo group showed higher bench press strength. No significant differences were found for other outcomes.
population_specificity: Untrained, recreationally active adults aged 18-35 years.
effective_dosage: 350 mg Levagen+ (equivalent to 300 mg PEA) daily, split into two 175 mg doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ultramicronized palmitoylethanolamide combined with luteolin in treating post-COVID-19 critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP) and positioning-related peripheral nerve injuries (PNI).
results_summary: The study reported successful treatment of a 71-year-old man with post-COVID-19 CIP and PNI using the combination therapy, suggesting potential neuroprotective, neurotrophic, and anti-inflammatory benefits. The findings advocate for larger clinical trials to confirm these advantages.
population_specificity: A 71-year-old Italian man with post-COVID-19 CIP and positioning-related PNI of the left upper extremity.
effective_dosage: 400 mg ultramicronized palmitoylethanolamide plus 40 mg ultramicronized luteolin (Glìalia), two tablets a day 12 hours apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of PEA encapsulated in phytosomes in attenuating experimental ulcerative colitis in rodents and humans.
results_summary: PEA at a human-equivalent dose reduced clinical signs of colitis, mucosal injury, and leukocyte recruitment in DSS-induced experimental colitis, demonstrating beneficial effects in controlling acute intestinal inflammation.
population_specificity: Rodents and humans with experimental ulcerative colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel combination including Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in modulating oxidative stress, inflammation, and myelination mechanisms in neuropathic pain.
results_summary: The study found that the combination, including PEA, could cross the intestinal barrier, reach the peripheral nervous system, and modulate oxidative stress, inflammation, and myelination under Schwann cell damage, suggesting potential efficacy in treating neuropathic pain.
population_specificity: Not specified (general neuropathy population implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ultramicronized Palmitoylethanolamide (umPEA) in managing neuropathic pain (NP) in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) already receiving immunoglobulin therapy.
results_summary: UmPEA significantly improved NP symptoms (p = 0.0007) and quality of life (p = 0.0036) when added to immunoglobulin therapy, suggesting it is a safe and effective adjunct treatment.
population_specificity: 14 patients with CIDP undergoing immunoglobulin therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of topical palmitoylethanolamide (Levagen+) compared to a standard moisturizer in reducing eczema severity and improving patient outcomes.
results_summary: Levagen+ significantly reduced eczema symptom severity, including redness, dryness, and total POEM score, compared to the comparator cream over 4 weeks.
population_specificity: Adults aged over 18 with atopic eczema on their hands or arms.
effective_dosage: Applied topically twice daily (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) with a combination of pregabalin and nortriptyline in treating post-extraction trigeminal neuropathy, using pain intensity and MRI changes as outcomes.
results_summary: Palmitoylethanolamide significantly reduced pain scores with negligible side effects, though the combination therapy showed the highest reduction in pain. PEA was effective for mild to moderate pain with minimal adverse effects.
population_specificity: 60 patients with post-extraction trigeminal neuropathy (20 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of co-micronized palmitoylethanolamide (PEA)/polydatin (PD) in treating abdominal pain symptoms in pediatric patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The co-micronized PEA/PD group showed significantly more patients achieving complete remission (IBS-SSS score <75) compared to placebo, particularly in the IBS-diarrhea subtype, with notable reductions in abdominal pain intensity and frequency. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients aged 10-17 years with IBS meeting Rome IV criteria.
effective_dosage: Administered three times daily (specific dosage amount not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a bioavailable form of PEA (Levagen+®) on serum BDNF levels and cognitive function in healthy adults.
results_summary: PEA supplementation significantly increased serum BDNF levels and improved memory performance, as evidenced by better first success and fewer errors on the Paired Associates Learning test.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (n = 39)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) supplementation could effectively and safely reduce migraine pain, duration, and rescue medication use compared to a placebo.
results_summary: PEA supplementation (Levagen+) resolved more headaches after 2- and 8 hours, reduced pain scores at 1.5 and 4 hours, and significantly decreased rescue medication use compared to placebo, with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Otherwise healthy young to middle-aged adults, predominantly female, experiencing migraines.
effective_dosage: 600 mg of PEA (Levagen+) taken upon migraine onset, with an optional second dose after 2 hours if symptoms persisted.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention with follow-up for 4 hours or until migraine resolution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in reducing intraocular pressure (IOP) in patients with eye disorders, particularly glaucoma.
results_summary: PEA demonstrated significant efficacy in reducing IOP in patients, supporting its clinical use for glaucoma and other eye disorders. The systematic review included six studies (199 patients), with three studies used for meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Patients with eye disorders, including glaucoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether micronized/ultramicronized Palmitoylethanolamide (m/umPEA) improves neuropsychiatric sequelae (depression, fatigue, chronic pain, and subjective well-being) in COVID-19 survivors.
results_summary: Patients treated with m/umPEA showed greater improvement in depression and fatigue compared to the control group, but no significant changes were observed in chronic pain or subjective well-being. The treatment's benefits were independent of age, sex, and baseline neuropsychiatric status.
population_specificity: COVID-19 survivors with neuropsychiatric manifestations (n=98, with 57 receiving m/umPEA and 41 as controls).
